messages: cc097e0d7183ae8436e7df709553c8c0 (00:13): ponders about DanC's request for everyone to put disclaimers on most things they say
e3fb62ebfa4f36acf5cbff6a6ed0f2e0 (00:15): it's just for public-html-comments
e3fb62ebfa4f36acf5cbff6a6ed0f2e0 (00:15): and might not count for editors
e3fb62ebfa4f36acf5cbff6a6ed0f2e0 (00:16): rejoices
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (00:17): wants HTML mail just so he can use 20em disclaimers, in red.
cc097e0d7183ae8436e7df709553c8c0 (00:17): oh, i thought it was intended for public-html.
e3fb62ebfa4f36acf5cbff6a6ed0f2e0 (00:19): no
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (00:20): wonders if he should retroactively disclaim things he said earlier
e3fb62ebfa4f36acf5cbff6a6ed0f2e0 (00:21): if you do, mention my name as well :)
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (00:22): Well I was thinking I would have to email the list again, but that seems antisocially noisy, so maybe private email to the original posters
f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (00:26): I think the disclaimers is a bad idea
f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (00:27): everyone's comments should just be considered to be personal opinion, unless it explicitly states it's on behalf of the working group
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (00:27): f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220: they seem unnecessary to me too, and very hard to write well
cc097e0d7183ae8436e7df709553c8c0 (00:27): i guess a boilerplate to include anytime we send to -comments seems easiest
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (00:28): For example saying "I think foo but that doesn't represent the opinion of the WG" suggests the WG thinks "not foo"
cc097e0d7183ae8436e7df709553c8c0 (00:28): with probably just a link to DanC's email requesting disclaimers
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (00:28): what does it mean for a working group to have an opinion anyway?
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (00:28): especially one with 500+ people
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (00:29): 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e: It seems to mean that we have taken a formal vote on something

3f2e2531201cfbf853f16f668132eaf2 (00:29): You can say "The working group has decided X" (or, if there is an assumption that you are speaking on behalf of the working group, just say "X"), and that doesn't involve opinions
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (00:30): prefers the whatwg style
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (00:30): where everyone just has their own opinions
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (00:30): and there's no attempt at pretending that everyone agrees on everything (or anything)
e3fb62ebfa4f36acf5cbff6a6ed0f2e0 (00:32): Acid3 test 76 (unwritten) is interesting

3f2e2531201cfbf853f16f668132eaf2 (00:33): http://google.com/search?q=cache:kqZmhh_nOjEJ:hixie.ch/tests/evil/acid/003/NOT_READY_PLEASE_DO_NOT_USE.html - I guess that's an unsupported way of running the test
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (00:33): it's certainly not a way that's going to be very useful
cc097e0d7183ae8436e7df709553c8c0 (00:34): having a quirks mode acid test isn't such a bad idea
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (00:35): if there was a spec...
cc097e0d7183ae8436e7df709553c8c0 (00:36): yep, writing it is on my to-do list ;)
e3fb62ebfa4f36acf5cbff6a6ed0f2e0 (00:37): thanks to Acid2 there's at least one additional quirk in the HTML parser :-(
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (00:37): i know the feeling
e3fb62ebfa4f36acf5cbff6a6ed0f2e0 (00:37): <p><table>
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (00:37): that's been a quirk for years, in compliant browsers like mozilla
cc097e0d7183ae8436e7df709553c8c0 (00:37): so was lack of sgml comment parsing
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (00:38): yeah well that's a different case
e3fb62ebfa4f36acf5cbff6a6ed0f2e0 (00:38): neh
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (00:38): <p><table/></p> is dumb, at least given our model in html5
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (00:38): i don't regret forcing that issue at all
cc097e0d7183ae8436e7df709553c8c0 (00:39): i agree that standards mode parsing of <p><table> makes more sense, but i'd rather it worked the same in both quirks and no-quirks
cc097e0d7183ae8436e7df709553c8c0 (00:39): granted, i don't know how many pages would break if we did standards mode parsing of <p><table> in quirks mode too
e3fb62ebfa4f36acf5cbff6a6ed0f2e0 (00:41): enough for it to matter last i checked
cc097e0d7183ae8436e7df709553c8c0 (00:41): how did you check?
cc097e0d7183ae8436e7df709553c8c0 (00:42): the knowledge that pages contain <p><table> doesn't mean that those will necessarily break when parsing as standards mode

cc097e0d7183ae8436e7df709553c8c0 (00:43): i mean, if there's no matching css and scripts doesn't depend on it, and the trailing </p> after the table creates an empty P, then it will probably be rendered the same
